across.text: Man United stew about a possible pen?
across.explanation: MUTE SWAN(i.e. “a possible pen” – a pen is a female swan. The mute swan, meanwhile, is another name for the common swan. So a swan, then). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “about”) of MAN, U (a recognised abbreviation of “united”) and STEW.

across.text: Way a long tooth cut finds place
across.explanation: STATUS(i.e. “place”). Solution is ST (i.e. “way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “street”) followed by A and TUSK (i.e. “long tooth”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “cut”), like so: ST-A-TUS.

across.text: Resident scholar Ginger knocked over by wild pig
across.explanation: BOARDER(i.e. “resident scholar”). Solution is RED (i.e. “ginger” – ignore the misleading capitalisation) reversed (indicated by “knocked over”) and placed “by” or after BOAR (i.e. “wild pig”), like so: BOAR-DER.

across.text: Sails across ocean and far away? Hardly
across.explanation: CLOSE AT HAND(i.e. “far away? Hardly”). Solution is CLOTH (i.e. “sails”) wrapped around or “across” SEA (i.e. “ocean”) and followed by AND, like so: CLO(SEA)TH-AND.

across.text: Corrupt senate has excellent backing that puts one out
across.explanation: ANAESTHESIA(i.e. “that puts one out”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “corrupt”) of SENATE HAS followed by AI (i.e. “excellent”, i.e. A1 using its Roman numeral equivalent – a common piece of wordplay used by setters) once reversed (indicated by “backing”), like so: ANAESTHES-IA.

across.text: Genesis performing selected songs?
across.explanation: ONSET(i.e. “genesis” or beginning). Solution is ON (i.e. “performing”) followed by SET (i.e. “selected songs”). Nicely worked.

across.text: Bishop presses son to become writer
across.explanation: AnthonyBURGESS(i.e. “writer”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “bishop” used in chess) followed by URGES (i.e. “presses”) and S (a recognised abbreviation of “son”).

across.text: Doctors set out at night to cover area
across.explanation: DENATURES(i.e. “doctors”). Solution is DENTURES (i.e. “set out at night”, as in how you’d probably not kip with them in) wrapped around or “covering” A (a recognised abbreviation of “area”), like so: DEN(A)TURES.

across.text: Such a fish as sinks beneath the waves?
across.explanation: TORPEDO. Solution satisfies a variety of “fish” also known as an electric ray, and “as sinks beneath the waves”, referring to the weapon used to sink ships.

across.text: Up north, pastiche irritated primitive sort
across.explanation: PITHECANTHROPUS(i.e. “primitive sort”, referring to “a fossil hominid discovered by Dutch palaeontologist Dr Eugene Dubois in Java in 1891-2”(Chambers)). “Irritated” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of UP NORTH PASTICHE. Wordplay was obvious but this took a few intersecting letters before I was able to brute-force my Chambers, because, let’s be honest, this isn’t exactly an everyday term is it? If this was the first clue you put into the grid then bully for you, but for the rest of us who didn’t take GCSE Anthropogeny I stand by my previous gripes about obscure general knowledge crap getting uselessly clued up as anagrams. Still, at least this wasn’t stuck in the grid to fill an awkward space!

across.text: Journeys to the bar and back?
across.explanation: ROUND TRIPS(i.e. “journeys to…and back”). Clue plays on people buying ROUNDS of drinks at a “bar”. You get the idea.

across.text: Commercial rubbish about one being skilled
across.explanation: ADROIT(i.e. “skilled”). Solution is AD (i.e. “commercial”, short for advertisement) followed by ROT (i.e. “rubbish”) once wrapped “about” I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”), like so: AD-RO(I)T.

across.text: Shorten extract from poet: Rimbaud
across.explanation: TRIM(i.e. “shorten”). “Extract from” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: POE(T RIM)BAUD.

across.text: Hopping mad, presumably?
across.explanation: NOT A HAPPY BUNNY. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole, but also plays on how BUNNIES “hop”. A genuinely witty clue that had me chuckling when I twigged it.

across.text: Singular craft needed to produce epigram?
across.explanation: ONE-LINER(i.e. “epigram” or short poem – one-liner might be pushing it, mind!) Solution is ONE (i.e. “singular”) followed by LINER (i.e. “craft” or sea vessel).

across.text: Plant pots not carelessly buried
across.explanation: ENTOMBED(i.e. “buried”). Solution is EMBED (i.e. “plant”) wrapped around or “potting” an anagram (indicated by “carelessly”) of NOT, like so: E(NTO)MBED.

across.text: Man’s expert knowledge about artist in border region
across.explanation: ALSACE-LORRAINE(i.e. former “border region” formed by the German empire and reverted back to French ownership after WWI). Solution is AL’S (i.e. “man’s”, basically a man’s name made possessive) followed by ACE (i.e. “expert”) and LORE (i.e. “knowledge”) once wrapped “about” RA (i.e. “artist”, specifically a Royal Academician) and IN, like so: AL’S-ACE-LOR(RA-IN)E.

across.text: Pub needs introduction to drummer and rhymer
across.explanation: BARD(i.e. “rhymer”). Solution is BAR (i.e. “pub”) followed by D (i.e. “introduction to drummer”, i.e. the first letter of “drummer”).

across.text: Unpleasant smell in small ditch rook must escape
across.explanation: STENCH(i.e. “unpleasant smell”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”) followed by TRENCH (i.e. “ditch”) once the R has been removed (indicated by “rook must escape” – R being a recognised abbreviation of “rook” used in chess), like so: S-TENCH.

across.text: What might be asset with mice spreading – answer welcomed?
across.explanation: SIAMESE CAT. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole, but is also an anagram (indicated by “spreading”) of ASSET, MICE and A (a recognised abbreviation of “answer”, as in Q&A).

across.text: Stage at which drinkers may drink no more?
across.explanation: SATURATION POINT. A relatively straightforward clue and solution.

across.text: Candidate turning on explosive energy
across.explanation: NOMINEE(i.e. “candidate”). Solution is ON reversed (indicated by “turning”) and followed by MINE (i.e. “explosive”) and E (a recognised abbreviation of “energy”), like so: NO-MINE-E.

across.text: Weller? He needs to change to receive greeting
across.explanation: HEALTHIER(i.e. “weller” – the question mark is an indicator the setter is being a bit loose). Solution is HE followed by ALTER (i.e. “to change”) once wrapped around or “receiving” HI (i.e. “greeting”), like so: HE-ALT(HI)ER. What a naff clue!

across.text: Recover from failed miracle
across.explanation: RECLAIM(i.e. “recover”). “Failed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of MIRACLE.

across.text: Weapon brought back before court causes bleed
across.explanation: EXACT(i.e. “bleed”, both meaning to extort money). Solution is AXE (i.e. “weapon”) reversed (indicated by “brought back”) and followed by CT (a recognised abbreviation of “court”), like so: EXA-CT.

across.text: John, Scots engineer holding monarch to his breast?
across.explanation: WATER CLOSET(i.e. “john”, slang for toilet). Solution is James WATT (i.e. “Scots engineer”) wrapped around or “holding” ER (i.e. “monarch”, specifically Elizabeth Regina) and CLOSE (i.e. “holding…to his breast”), like so: WAT(ER-CLOSE)T.

across.text: Pope’s defender penning short quote about Keats scholar?
across.explanation: ROMANTICIST(i.e. “Keats scholar”). Solution is ROMANIST (i.e. “Pope’s defender” or Roman Catholic) wrapped around or “penning” CITE (i.e. “quote”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “short”) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “about”), like so: ROMAN(TIC)IST.

across.text: Hardly active, Mike enters rave after party
across.explanation: DORMANT(i.e. “hardly active”). Solution is M (“Mike” in the phonetic alphabet) placed in or “entering” RANT (i.e. “rave”). This is all then placed “after” DO (i.e. “party”), like so: DO-R(M)ANT.

across.text: Duke and daughter to occupy Manchester town land
across.explanation: SADDLE(i.e. “land”, as in to burden or encumber another). Solution is D (a recognised abbreviation of “duke”) and D (ditto “daughter”) both placed in or “occupying” SALE (i.e. “Manchester town”), like so: SA(D-D)LE.

across.text: Top class batsman’s first to leave, and drive away
across.explanation: ESTRANGE(i.e. to “drive away”). Solution is BEST (i.e. “top”) and RANGE (i.e. “class”) with the B removed (indicated by “batsman’s first to leave”, i.e. the first letter of “batsman”), like so: EST-RANGE.

down.text: Skilled solver’s brother in Scots farmland the writer owns?
down.explanation: MYCROFT(i.e. “skilled solver’s brother”, i.e. Mycroft Holmes, brother of Sherlock Holmes). When written as MY CROFT the solution also satisfies “Scots farmland the writer owns” from the point of view of the setter.

down.text: Steal hearts perhaps in such attire?
down.explanation: TROUSER SUIT(i.e. “attire”). Solution is TROUSER (i.e. “steal”) followed by SUIT (i.e. “hearts perhaps”, other playing card suits are available). Nicely worked.

down.text: Extremist eviscerated on Highland peak in hut? There’s a hitch
down.explanation: SHEET BEND(i.e. “a hitch” – over to Chambers: “a type of knot used especially for joining ropes of different sizes”. A new one on me, but not one I fancy remembering). Solution is ET (i.e. “extremist eviscerated”, i.e. the word “extremist” with all its middle letters removed) and BEN (i.e. “Highland peak”) both placed “in” SHED (i.e. “hut”), like so: SHE(ET-BEN)D.

down.text: Disturbed, our phobias great, we lay down our lives for others
down.explanation: AUTOBIOGRAPHERS(i.e. “we lay down our lives for others” – nice misdirection). “Disturbed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of OUR PHOBIAS GREAT.

down.text: Prime Minister gone to shake out hay on moorland
down.explanation: TED HEATH(i.e. “Prime Minister” 1970-74). Solution is TED (i.e. “to shake out hay” for drying – another new one on me) followed by HEATH (i.e. “moorland”).

down.text: Mystical Pole in dream has any number of teeth
down.explanation: TRANSCENDENTAL(i.e. “mystical”). Solution is S (i.e. “pole” – ignore the misleading capitalisation, this is a recognised abbreviation of “south”) placed “in” TRANCE (i.e. “dream”) and followed by N (i.e. “any number”, mathematically speaking) and DENTAL (i.e. “of teeth”), like so: TRAN(S)CE-N-DENTAL.

down.text: Photograph intimidating woman, one encountered in bed
down.explanation: SNAPDRAGON(i.e. “one encountered in [flower] bed”). Solution is SNAP (i.e. “photograph”) followed by DRAGON (i.e. “intimidating woman”).

down.text: Helmet has function opener perhaps admits
down.explanation: BASINET(i.e. a kind of “helmet”). Solution is SIN (i.e. trigonometrical “function”, short for sine) placed in or “admitted” by BAIT (i.e. “opener perhaps”, if you’re a fish I guess), like so: BA(SIN)ET.

down.text: Maybe drawing around leader of Hindus – a Buddhist monk
down.explanation: ARHAT(i.e. “Buddhist monk”. Not something recognised by my Chambers, Collins Concise or Bradford’s. Oxford lists it but suggests it’s a saint or someone holiest-of-the-holy. Would a monk qualify? Who cares, it’s religion either way so let’s move on quickly). Solution is ART (i.e. “maybe drawing” – other art forms are available) wrapped “around” H (i.e. “leader of Hindus”, i.e. the first letter of “Hindus”) and A, like so: AR(H-A)T.

down.text: Eastern hand one detected in academic account
down.explanation: DESCRIPTION(i.e. “account”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “eastern”), SCRIPT (i.e. “hand” or writing) and I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) all placed “in” DON (i.e. “academic”), like so: D(E-SCRIPT-I)ON.

down.text: Blockheads among others curtailed check again
down.explanation: REASSESS(i.e. “check again”). Solution is ASSES (i.e. “blockheads”) placed “among” REST (i.e. “others”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “curtailed”), like so: RE(ASSES)S.

down.text: Fine horse lost to Barnet’s travelling show?
down.explanation: FAIR(i.e. “travelling show”). Solution is F (a recognised abbreviation of “fine” used in grading pencils) followed by HAIR (i.e. “Barnet”, after the cockney rhyming slang Barnet Fair, itself from a once-famous horse fair held there) once the H (i.e. “horse”, both slang names for heroin) has been removed (indicated by “lost”), like so: F-AIR.

down.text: Tropical fruit old man consumes always
down.explanation: PAPAYA(i.e. “tropical fruit”). Solution is PAPA (i.e. “old man” or father) wrapped around or “consuming” AY (i.e. shortened form of aye, or “always”), like so: PAP(AY)A.

down.text: Venomous American upset Republican
down.explanation: RATTLER(i.e. “venomous American”, short for rattlesnake). Solution is RATTLE (i.e. “upset”) followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “Republican”).

down.text: Some player in Germany who knows the ropes?
down.explanation: RINGER(i.e. “who knows the ropes”, a playful reference to bell-ringers). “Some” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: PLAYE(R IN GER)MANY.

down.text: Soldiers under charge detained in camp in holy orders
down.explanation: TEN COMMANDMENTS(i.e. “holy orders”). Solution is MEN (i.e. “soldiers”) placed after or “under” – this being a down clue – COMMAND (i.e. “charge”). This is all then placed “in” TENTS (i.e. “camp”), like so: TEN(COMMAND-MEN)TS.

down.text: Charitable and well-known ghost writer-in-chief?
down.explanation: PUBLIC-SPIRITED(i.e. “charitable”). Solution is PUBLIC (i.e. “well-known”) followed by SPIRIT (i.e. “ghost”) and ED (i.e. “writer-in-chief”, short for editor).

down.text: Forest with walnut finally burning
down.explanation: ARDENT(i.e. “burning”). Solution is ARDEN (i.e. “forest”, a reference to an area in Warwickshire that was once heavily wooded, apparently) followed by T (i.e. “walnut finally”, i.e. the last letter of “walnut”).

down.text: Cigar box cast from rhodium
down.explanation: HUMIDOR(i.e. “cigar box”). “Cast from” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of RHODIUM. Nicely worked.

down.text: Singular to be so politically incorrect?
down.explanation: SEXIST(i.e. “politically incorrect”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “singular”) followed by EXIST (i.e. “to be”).

down.text: Good health professional warm and adept?
down.explanation: TOASTMASTER(i.e. “good health professional”, a play on the words such a person would say). Solution is TOAST (i.e. to “warm”) and MASTER (i.e. “adept”).

down.text: Old Peruvian people accepting time for magical words
down.explanation: INCANTATION(i.e. “magical words”). Solution is INCA (i.e. “old Peruvian”) and NATION (i.e. “people”) all wrapped around or “accepting” T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), like so: INCA-N(T)ATION.

down.text: Some wines laid down in this pleasant situation?
down.explanation: BED OF ROSES(i.e. “pleasant situation”). Clue plays on ROSÉ being a variety of “wine” and how one “lays” in a BED. You get the idea.

down.text: French banker runs to embrace porky waiter
down.explanation: SOMMELIER(i.e. wine “waiter”). Solution is SOMME (i.e. “French banker”, specifically a river in northern France) and R (a recognised abbreviation of “runs” used in a number of ball games) all wrapped around or “embracing” LIE (i.e. “porky”, after the cockney rhyming slang, pork pie), like so: SOMME-(LIE)-R.

down.text: Avoided middle in test ground
down.explanation: ESCHEWED(i.e. “avoided”). Solution is ES (i.e. “middle in test”, i.e. the middle letters of “test”) followed by CHEWED (i.e. “ground”).

down.text: Gut sear with evil twists
down.explanation: VISCERAL(i.e. “gut”, in this case probably relating to instinct or intuition). “Twists” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SEAR and EVIL.

down.text: Hallucination allowed in some rhyming verses
down.explanation: TRIPLET(i.e. “some rhyming verses”). Solution is TRIP (i.e. “hallucination”) followed by LET (i.e. “allowed”).

down.text: Diminutive singer in Henley’s content to show style
down.explanation: ENTITLE(i.e. to “style”, not usage I can immediately put in a sentence, but it’s backed up by my Chambers). Solution is TIT (i.e. “diminutive singer” or songbird) placed “in” ENLE (i.e. “Henley’s content”, i.e. all the middle letters of Henley), like so: EN(TIT)LE.

down.text: Legally land chelonian reptile missing leg
down.explanation: TERRA(i.e. “legally land”, i.e. the Latin for “land” often used in legalese). Solution is TERRAPIN (i.e. “chelonian reptile”) with the PIN removed (indicated by “missing leg”, PIN being a slang word for one).

down.text: Month in service that’s perfect culminating point
down.explanation: ACME(i.e. “culminating point”). Solution is M (a recognised abbreviation of “month”) placed “in” ACE (i.e. “service that’s perfect”), like so: AC(M)E.
